Apperance: Yellow with a white head.
Aroma: Citric notes, Funk, Brett, Hay.
Taste: Citric notes, White bread, Hay, Wheat.
Palate: High carbonation and some tartness. Goes down easy!

A really good american-sour but not worth the chase for us europeans with easy access to 3F and Cantillon.
Bottle from 2013. Aroma of fruity jam with some acidity. Fruity, sour taste. Really balanced. Tasty. Tastes better than I thought it would.

Very happy I finally got to try this beer. 2013 vintage. Golden pour with a white head. The aroma and flavor are both awesome. In the aroma I get some lemon and biscuit malt notes as well as some light tartness. The flavor is also great but is more complex. I get some acidic lemon notes at first but things then get interesting. I get a little bit of light funk as well as some light cheesy notes, some alcohol, pepper and grass. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. An awesome sour beer.
Bottle..Pour is golden with a thin white head..Nose is oak, some wine , dry, berries, wet oak..Taste is berries, tartness, oak, funk, dry,

An absolutely phenomenal beer. One of those beer experiences that sticks with you. Aromas are intense sour lemon and other citrus. Flavors are lemon juice and just sour goodness. Smooth palate. You can taste the love this was made with.
UPDATED: MAR 15, 2014 Shared by Josh at Hunahpu 14 (big thanks!). Gold pour. Nice sharp lemon citrus and oak. Pretty sour. Juicy. Funk. Really good. 8.6

Bottle, thanks to Nick, tasted on 01/31/2014. Pours dark golden orange, clear, light haze on the surface, thin ring of lacing. Aroma is tart lemon, apricots, sweet hay, vanilla, moderate barnyard funk, touch acetic, wood. Taste is bracing tart lemon, very acetic, vinegar, slick citrus overtones, vanilla, wood, sharp funk. Light body, dry. Not my favorite, but decent American sour.

bottle shared by tom10101, many thanks dude. pours hazy light yellow with a small whtie cap, some retention and lacing. moderate funk, white grapes, slightly buttery, nice fruitiness - pears and peaches, grass, herbs, wood - hint of vanilla, hint of sweetness - candi-like, medium acidity - lactic, acetic and citric - almost puckering. average to moderate carbonation, light body - oily, silky mouthfeel, dry and tart grassy-herbal-citrusy finish. nice interpretation. just a little something missing, perhaps funk, or some almost overwhelming components like acetic acid and diacetyls, for it to be worldclass. still.. it is tasty and good.

Huge thanks to tom10101 for sharing this one, thanks again Tommy! This rating is for a bottle from batch 2. Pours a nice golden with a small white rim that leaves some lacing. Aroma is fruity and acidic, a bit of acetic acid but mostly just lactic. It feels like a genuine gueuze and begs for a taste. Taste is indeed tart and puckering, full of peaches and apricots. There is some slightly distracting acetic acid but other than that it is really enjoyable. Body is light, carbonation medium. Really nice and definitely a top-10 american sour.

Alright you stupid dickwads, heres the judgment - batch 2

Pours a golden ale with some etched tops of whites. Some lemon, some sweet wheat and a little....marshmallow?! There is a bit of flintstone vitamin chewables in the nose. Flavor follows plenty sour, lots of lemon, lots of lactic and acetic acid, mostly lactic. Theres a clean mildly citric character. Body is thin with moderately hi carb and a dry finish. I think this is a good beer, Im skeptical to seek out more bottles.

Bottle. This was worth the wait. This could be the best sour Ive ever had. You get a big sour fruity tingle in your nose when you smell it, then it wrecks your face. Tart, sour, bitter, funky, fruity, fizzy, sweet. You get it all. Plus the label is pretty cool.

(bottle - 750 ml) Clear gold pour. Huge sour and funky tart aroma without much else. No additional fruit required. Flavor is dry and punch your face off sour. This is what I want in a sour ale. Nothing extra needed, no apologies wanted... just enamel peeling sour goodness. I wish I had a case of it in front of me right now. Utterly phenomenal.
2013 bottle shared during some post-bus drinking at the Downtown Inn for RBWG. Delicious lemon sorbet flavor. Perfectly lactic and tangy with a hint of apple cider vinegar. Awesome stuff!

750 ml bottle to snifter (Batch 2; generously shared by someone at RBWG. Looks good; a hazy light golden orange with white lacing. Smells and tastes tart, oaky, and funky. Nice and lively on the palate. Great stuff!

Draft at Monks during a Lost Abbey dinner. Hazy peach pour with a ring of foam. Juicy Fruit gum. Sweethearts. Apricots. Peaches. Fresh oak planks. Orange marmalade. Huge fruity flavors with a nice sour punch. Fuller body and more complex than expected. Fantastic!

Fantastic exciting to try this thanx to a friend. Bottle. Fruity fruity nose first sip is huge acidic sourness almost tasted like it reacted in my mouth a warmed up. A slight cherry note. Cloudy, no real head. Very refreshing awesomeness!!!
Had at the BGoA Winter tasting. Wow. Pours a hazy golden. Tart and sour but really nice. Clean and fresh. Really nice.

A really top notch sour that does it right. Pours a copper golden color with fizzy white head. Aroma is red wine. spicy oak, balsamic vinegar, bright grapey notes. Taste is heavy tart with a lot of vanilla and spicy oak and vinous character. Light sweetness is inviting to cut the sour. GReAT

Bottle, latest release. The pout is golden yellow. The aroma is all sour. The taste is a little more sour for my liking, salty taste to it. Not puckering sour though. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours unclear blonde , small white head 
Smells buttery sour 
Taste is sour , but not sharp . Oaky , not much funk or dryness . Very good carbonation 
Very drinkable . 
Doesnt live up to the rather extreme value , yet i am happy i have a second one .

Pours a very light orange pour, nice clarity but no hed formed. 
The nose has a very incredibly funky nose. Like the funkiest most earthy cheese with leather and lemons and fresh cut grass.
Hmm, this is pretty good. Its very sour but then fades away quickly to a sauvignon quality. Another wild ale that reminds me of lemon heads and sour candies. salt & vinegar chips and maybe some pickle juice. Its good but Im glad this bottle was split a few ways. Its insanely intense and loaded with sour. Very nice but needs to be split 4 ways

Bottle; Pour is fairly murky medium gold, with a modest fine bubbled white head into this stemware ; The nose is dusty, grasses, peppery spices; it moves to some light citrus and peach. The appearance isnt impressive ; the aroma didnt overly impress either. The flavor profile (I found) was stunning. Initial light bitter, tart, somewhat puckering - and it reveals a depth of character after a touch of warmth from the original pour. Lemongrass, grapefruit, peach, dusty oak, with white pepper and spent grain, moving to a prickly carbonation, and a dry, exquisite finish. Im very thankful for this one

2013 bottle. Opened 12/28/13. Clear straw yellow orange color. Big funky nose. A hint of fruity ness. Very tart up front, and continuing across the palate. Big lemon notes, and a perfect sour quality. Not overwhelming at all, and then leaves you wanting more. So good.

Bottle. Pours a clear golden color with a decent white head. Aroma strong of tart notes, light caramel, malt, with a hint of fruit in the background. Flavor. Medium tartness that doesnt leave you hurting. Excellent balance. Smooth texture. An excellent beer.

Pours clear yellow, minimal white head

Smell light citrusy melon, big tropical fruit, bit of funk

Taste very tart, lactic, oak and citrus, tangerine sour, very nice tartness, oaky vanilla in finish, lot of qualities of lemonaid

Lighter bodied

Great

Sampled at a friends tasting. Pours hazy golden with a white head. Aroma strong of sour and tart notes, light caramel and pale malts, and very light hints of fruit. Flavor perfectly balanced for a very sour ale. Smooth texture. A really good beer.

750ml bottle, thanks to DanielCoor for sharing this one! 2013 vintage. Mildly hazy golden color. Thin khaki head. Leaves nice reaches of lace. Very nice big puckering sour taste. Bigger body. Smooth crisp carbonation. Wheaty, oaky, lemony citrusy lightly funky aroma, very nice.. Awesome, super tasty geuze. Delicious!!

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2013 Bottle: 2013... thanks, Mike! Golden-yellow body with mild clarity all around, capped with a fizzy white head that fades to a small collar in moments. Aroma contains some sharp acidity, stone fruit sourness, white grapes, vinous notes, very slight vinegar, oak, light sweaty funk, & a big helping of yogurt-y lacto tartness from start to finish. Taste is very sour & tart with mellow acidity, sour lacto, apple skins, vinous white grapes, oak barrel, lemon, mild yogurt, small boozy presence, & a slightly funky finish along the lines of wet bales of hay. Tart, almost wine-like aftertaste. This stuff is right in my wheelhouse... fantastic sour ale.

Bottle at Exira Beer Summit IV. Thanks to adnielsen for bringing this bottle. Pours a golden color with white head. Funky, cheese, horseblanket, barn aromas. Cheese, barnyard, funky, slight lemon/citrus flavors. Fun beer to try.

Bottle @ Exira Beer Summit IV, Day 2. Thanks to womencantsail for sending! 750mL bottle, 2013 release. Pours a touch hazy golden yellow appearance with a white head. Funky/lemony, spritzy, cobweb/attic musty, guava/pineapple aroma. Cheesy, barnyard funk, lemon, big guava, pineapple, and dusty flavor. Fairly sour finish. Nice funk and quite delicious but not up to par with many Belgian counterparts. Thank you again, Andrew!

Man är ju lite svag för hype, det är ju bara att erkänna. En trade med en trevlig amerikan (thanks Stupac2!). Stått och lurat i källaren ett tag nu. En av kvällens höjdpunkter på raritetsprovning. Doften är lagom funkig. Drag av ättika och citrusfrukter. Frisk och härlig. Helt klar i utseende. Svagt brödig. Viss ättika även i smaken och viss komplexitet. Lost abbey har imponerat!
mikem409 is my dawg. hooked me up with this beauty after smoking a corned beef brisket that melted my face with excellence.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2014 At my place with Thomas, Scott and Samantha. Pours yellow/ neon orange. Aroma is musky, funky, light mold, lactic, acidic, nice. Taste is smooth, mouth melting, fizzy, orange, lemon, orange peel, very savor, and lasting flavor. zesty. 

Additional rating at GABF 2013. Pours light orange clear, creamy medium sized head. Aroma is citric orange sour, lemon, kinda clean on the note. Taste is sour lemon, citrus, delicious, medium high acidic. finish is medium length with mouth puckering note on the end that works. 4.3

Bottle at Bruces new pad, from an IP trade with a guy from CA, 15/10/13.
Hazed orange with a thin off white covering.
Nose is tarte fruit, good dose of funkability, grassy, bitter orange, lemon sherbet, dank straw.
Taste comprises tarte orange, dank straw, light must, subtle acidic tang, lemon rind, funky.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation with a crisp finale.
Top draw !
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: A fascinating brew. Had at 2013GABF. Very sour tart and slight salt flavor, along with oak character. What was great is it did not ave the typical medicinal manufactured character. This was a true aged funk, bacteria melody! Body and mouthfeel and efferveciant carbonation was exquisite.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2014 750 ml bottle - 2013 vintage - shared with Urbain Coutteau. Pours light hazy yellow with a small fine bubbly head. Looks like a charm. Subtle and mellow nose of butter flower, lemon zeste, some oak. Smooth body, slight sourness but soft as silk. Would have loved a bit more of punch as with the Cable Car. Overall a very nice sour! Excited to try the 2009 next to it. -- Upped with 0.2 after having tried the 2009 version, which is softer than the 2013 one, held up very well.

2013 750-ml bottle (thank you, jpdurden24). Hazy lemon yellow in color with a frothy white head and spotty lacing. The nose features light lactic funk, hay, tart lemon, barnyard, and a light grassy note. Graceful, layered flavor of sour citrus, lemon meringue, slight orange and melon, with a tart finish that doesnt overpower the well-balanced taste. Effervescent and slightly prickly palate. This one is as good as advertised.

750 ml corked and caged bottle thanks to my friend Patrick. Thanks for opening this before I had to leave! Pours a slightly hazy copper with a thin white head of foam around the edges of the glass. The aroma has notes of apricot, earth, and some funk. The taste is sour, but not overly aggressive. In a few years, the sourness on this bad boy should be awesome. Right now, though, its just a more mellow funk that is easy drinking. Really glad I got to try this.
a few samples at GABF. nice funky nose with notes of citrus. clear golden pour. medium body with pedio notes, barnyard, and some lactic acid. excellent mouthfeel. brilliant sour finish.
At Darkness Day 2013, thanks StFun!!! Pour is light orange with white head. Aroma is funky and very tart. Sour, mouth-puckering in a way, a bit acetic. Really sour but good, very enjoyable beer.
In line @ Darkness Day 2013. Pours golden with a white head. Sour, fruity and funky aroma. Flavor is sour and fruity. I really like this one.

2013 bottle. Thanks to Paul for sharing this! Pours pale, gold, lightly hazy. Aroma: wine, funk; tart, juice, crisp - acetic; light body, avg carb, long biting acetic finish, moderate sweet, just a hint of salt?, lasting sour finish.
Yummy! Shared by StFun at Darkness Day - thanks!! Lovely sour nose and taste. A bit a harsh, but in a good way. Really nice.

Bottle thanks to Ontape ! Pours a slightly hazy yellow orange color with a finger of gaseous bubbles. The nose is a bit swampy, with a trace of sulphur, stonefruit and a some brett funk. The palate is beautiful, with great balance between funk fruit and acidity. Lemon, grapefruit, guava, pineapple and dusty barrel funk with a great lingering acidity... but not so much that it burns. This shit is legit. Wish I had more... Ontape ? Calling Ontape ?

Bottle at Bruces, thanks Colin. It pours hazy pale orange with a medium white head. The nose is creamy, orange, apricot, sherbet, lactic, juicy fruits, wood, vanilla and toasted coconut. The taste is crisp, tart, orange, apricot, peach, lactic, wood, moderate acidity, sherbet. creamy and lime pith with a dry, tart finish. Medium body and fine, prickly carbonation. Not a whole lot of depth, but it is rather delicious. Very drinkable.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2014 On draft at GABF. I probably went back 4 times for this one as all my friends had congregated near by. Needless to say it was tasty. Funky, feet, horse blanket, with dry lemon citric finish. Quite tart with some oak. Hells yea.
sampled at gabf. from my notes. had to get get back in line for a second tasting. straw yellow with a small fizzy head. sour lemon yeast and wine taste. great beer. #gabf

Bottle cheers to Colin. Pours a hazy, yet vibrant orange with a white head leaving sticky lacing. Nose is very juicy and zesty. Funk isnt overwhelming. Loads of lemon in this one, light acidity on the aroma with bubblegum and sweet sherbert notes. Lemon sherbert almost sums up the taste with a bit of funk to go with it. Quite zesty with orange rind and more lemon kick. Moderate acidity on the finish. Quite a juicy and tangy sour which I think works nicely

Bottle shared at Bruces in London - many thanks to Colin! Pours cloudy yellow with a frothy white head. Nose has rich and tangy lemon, good tang. Light to medium sweet flavor with sturdy acidic bite, sour and lightly jammy lemons, a bit of funk. Medium bodied with fine, spritzy carbonation. Well and sour to finish, moderately acidic, further jammy and tangy lemons. Solid.
Sampled at GABF 2013. Gold and hazy with a white head. Tart, light citrus and sour with chalky yeast, wine and oak. Finishes dry and refreshing.

A: Hazy Golden Straw Hue, Passes Some Light, Thin White Head Ring, Mild Lacing

S: Apricots, Hay, Mild Yeast, Mild Oak

T: Lemons, Apricots, Hay

M: Average Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Semi Tart

Overall, so solid...bitter and balanced, so appreciative to Nate for sharing this amazing bottle.
Pours a cloudy gold. Flavor is moderately tart. Notes of oak, vineagar apple and grape.

Bottle, sampled multiple times at GABF. Pour is slightly hazy yellow with a big frothy white head and good lacing. Funky, citrusy, light urine, heavy oaky, floral, light grassy and fresh smelling. Taste is big acid, white wine vinegar, again very big oak notes, a hint of spice in there, citrus, pineapple, and doughy. Light body with high carbonation. Nice sour for sure, but doesnt live up to the hype for me. Would love to try Batch 1.

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2016 Sample at GABF 2013. Pours hazy golden with a white head. Aroma of big tart fruit, lactic notes, wood and vinous aspects. Flavour is heavy acidic. Medium bodied with light carbonation.

Sample @ GABF 13. Pours a cloudy blonde beer with a stable white head on top. Aroma is birch, grapes and some vineous characters as well. Flavour has a big tart base backed up by a big vineous influence. Well balanced. Great palate cleanser for sure. Nice brew.
On draft at the GABF in 2013. Pours a hazy gold with an off white head. Barnyard nose with some tart apple. Moderate carbonation. Soft mouthfeel. Tart finish.

This beer has put in some time in the dojo since the first release, because it has definitely leveled up into an incredible American Wild, possibly my favorite ever. Reminds me of a lemon square. Damn impressive.

Pours a golden orange with a small, tight white head. Aroma is citrus, red wine and some barnyard funk. Perfect balance of citrus and sour. what makes this beer one of the best I have ever had is the hint of red wine notes. Unbelievable balance! Amazing beer!

Bottle through trade from Chris, hazy golden orange color with minimal head. Aroma is big sweet and tart lemons, subtle rich wine notes and some oak. Taste is a big tart lemon up front and finishes into big white wine character, jaw is tingling from the pucker and cheeks drying from the tannins. Probably one of the best sours I have had.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

October 6, 2013 - Bottle shared by Brandon. Cloudy yellow orangish pour with some head that faded quickly. Aroma was woody, white wine, funky, vinegar and maybe even a little rotten egg, which wasnt a bad thing. Taste was just an amazing mix of funk, wood and sweetness. Wow, this was just fantastic, best sour I have had to date. Thanks Brandon!

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2013 75cl, Vintage 2013, exclusive American brew, from De Hopduvel Gent, very complex sour brew, woody/sour and slightly vinous/fruity, balanced, cloudy, small head, very good brew, yet very expensive!

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2014 Sampled from a bottle at Where the Wild Beers Are - October 5, 2013. Was fortunate enough to get a nice full pour of this. Light orange pour, white head. Hay, lemon, fruit, and funk. Crisp and clean. Delicious!

750ml bottle .. 2013 Version .. . Pours a deep peach gold .. mild foam .. . medium fruitiness, the tartness is mild- very drinkable .. thought this would be more sour, very tame. but an enjoyable libation .. . . youre skating on thin ice while crying in a bucket..

29 sept 2013, bottle (2013 edition). Light orange and a tad cloudy. Nose is brett, oak, and cobwebs. Thin body and almost flat. Brett with sufficient sour and some oak. Really nice! Not too sour, faintly sweet. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared as a birthday gift from a friend. Semi-cloudy orange pour with a medium white head. Aroma of funk, lemon and oak. Funky flavor with red wine and oak character before a tart lemon finish.
Sampled at Kennys. Golden and hazy. A funky fruity nose. All kind of funk in here. Nice fruit including lemon. Some bret. Very good.

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2013 Excellent beer. Smells amazing and tastes just as good. I dont know if it lives up to the hype -- or the price -- and I dont know if anything could, really. Still glad I dealt with the screwed up online release and drove two hours to grab some. Reminds me of an aged Supplication without the cherries. Looking forward to revisiting in a few months. Bottom line: its a delicious sour.

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2015 Batch 2 bottle; notes from Saturday's tasting.Aroma has a light but present funkiness with moderate pineapple notes. Fairly acidic with a strong citrus character.Pours a cloudy pale yellow with a thin white head that recedes but is replenished but constant bubbles coming to the top. Faint lacing and no legs.Flavor is similar to the aroma with medium low barnyard funkiness. Fairly tart with a citric and lactic character. Lots of pineapple juiciness. Medium bodied with medium high carbonation. Low astringency and low alcohol warmth.Overall a very enjoyable American sour. There was quite a bit of acidity and pineapple juice but it could be a bit drier and with more barnyard character. It kind of reminds me of a young Beatification with less funk and a lot more pineapple.

Update - with age an odd apricot character has appeared in the aroma, but not fresh apricots, weird old ones.

2013 DDG. Pours a clear golden yellow with a small white head. Smell is pungent funky citrus, peaches, lemon rind, wet grass and a little pineapple. Taste sour peaches and lemon, a lot of fruit shines in this beer with a little hay and hops in the finish. Medium bodied very lots of carbonation. Another good beer by the Lost Abbey!

Golden yellow. Great fizz with light head. Beautiful aroma, well balanced acidity with just the right amount of sourness. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

7/13/13. 750mL with big thanks to womencantsail for this garbage palate cleanser we used among all the awesome malt likkas today. Funky, earthy, leathery nose with tons of funk, sour, and hay. Hugely sour flavor with lots of funk, some wood and vanilla, and lots of rar. Delish!
Strong tart nose with fruit notes drying finish. Slightly retired taste. Mega thanks to dr owl for bottle share at the rare malt likka tasting.
Lemon rind nose. Sniffer might be broken by malt Likka. Super tart and dry. Amazing.

Bottle from the 2009 Sinners Club.  This shit was amazing.  Yellowish colored pour with a white head on it.  Smell was funky, fruity, a little bit of hops, and some lemon.  Taste was smooth, almost refreshing, sour, little bit of bitterness, just a great beer.  If I did not know better I would think this was from Belgium.  Now if only I knew I needed a basket to drink it with, that probably would have made me give it a 5.1.
UPDATED: JAN 7, 2014 Tart and lastosy, rich thick orange juice, sharp sharp tang, great stuff.

Bottle opened last October at Matty and Marks Bar in MNSP. Pours a hazy straw yellow to light orange. White head is definitely there, not flat at all. Aroma is slightly peach, hay, vinegar, aromatic citrus peal. Taste is a very dry sour with very little fruit left. Some mild stone fruit but nothing crazy at this point. Vinegar again but in a nice way. One of the best American wild/sours opened that night.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text: Bottle. Yellow a bit hazy beer with a miniml head. Citrus, sourish, a bit rubber abd fruity aroma. Citrus, lemon, tart, vinegar, sourish and rubber flavour. To much vinegar taste :-(

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2013 750mL bottle, pours a hazy golden orange with a medium white head. Aroma of complex wild yeasts, lightly tart fruits and some peach-like tropical fruits. Flavour is intensely complex, full of wild yeast, tart light fruits (peach especially), and a bit of oak - difficult to describe as this is unlike anything Ive tried. Dominated by the peaches / apricots, and complex wild yeasts. A level of depth that Ive not experienced before in a sour. Amazing complexity and such a pleasure to drink. One of the best sours Ive had - exceptional.

This brew is a slightly hazy golden color with a thin white head that disappears quickly, leaving an outer ring. Short strings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of funky fruit, hay and malt. Medium-bodied with a vinous character and flavors of funky yeast, citrus and wood. The finish is funky with a lingering zesty citrus aftertaste. Good beer overall.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2013 finally get to try it after not trading for one years ago. This one has reached whale status. It is a good typical sour from LA, but with a nice bit of funk. Had it again. Lactic sourness, medium funk level, tropical fruits, a very well-balanced sour.

Pours out an attractive, well carbonated golden color with a small white head. Aroma is very complex, oak, funk, lemon, tart sourness, light fruit and damp basement make up the aroma. Taste is as complex as the aroma if not more, oak, nice tart funkiness without going too overboard, light sweet fruity notes, barnyard, tart sourness, hay, lemons, and more funk. Wow...this was good.

Bottle. Pours a lightly hazed gold with a stiff white head. Nose is freshly acidic, lactic acid, lemons and some malt vinegar. Fruity overall with some peach as well. On tasting, big bitterness, earthy and grassy. Strong vinegar notes on finish. Lemon skin and tart, dry finish. The vinegar notes make me a bit sad as Id love if this were dryer and more lactic overall. Still, a very interesting beer overall and glad I finally opened this up.

Thanks Mike! Peach-colored body brings with it some white head which fades quickly. The fizz emits a pleasantly lemony aroma, layered with sour yeast and oak. Love the noses intensity; hopefully this tastes as good as it smells.

Liquid meets tongue, taste buds rejoice. Tart lemons, oak, sharply acetic, mildly barnyard-esque, plus a unique kiss of sweetness to shake things up. Lemon meringue pie in a glass.

Reminds me of Cable Car, though I prefer the blend of flavors here. An excellent American sour.

Bottle generously shared by Grumpyoldtroll,  at our pre thanksgiving tasting...Thanks Mike!

I have been wanting to try this one for a while!

Poured a hazy apricot like color with minimal head.  The nose on this one was amazingly tart, slight funk mixed with lemon juice.

Taste follows suit on the tartness.  hint of lemon rhind mixed with sour berries.  This was surprisingly dry on the palate.  Smooth from sip to finish.  Overall this is an amazing geuze

750ml bottle thanks to one of you. I came into this expecting a gueuze and I will review it as such. Bright orange color with almost no head at all but it is carbonated. Smells sour and a bit cheesy but i would not say funky at all. In fact this does not smell like a true gueuze at all. The taste was way too sweet and then followed by a sourness. The sweetness was almost like a pixie stick or sweet tart and I didnt like that aspect at all.There was some citrus and fruit but to call this a gueuze is just not being honest. As a wild ale this was ok but the price was completely out of line for the beer that is in the bottle. Save your money and get a Cantillon for half the price.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 06-06-2011 00:52:18

Bottle, thx David for sharing. Beautiful hazy bright yellow-gold pour with smallish white head. Aroma is quite acetic, pineapple fruitiness, honey, funk, light butterness, lots and lots of wood. Taste is slightly acetic as well, a bit of citrus fruit, quite american tasting for a pseudo lambic but very tasty nonetheless. Slightly thicker palate than the previous bottles, well carbed with a strong sour finish.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2014 Bottle 750ml. Thx David. (B1)
Pours blond/orange with almost no head (white). Some lacing. Aroma is of fruits, pineapple, sweetness, funk. Taste is of fruits (pineapple), acid acetic, citrus, funk, barnyard. Palate: ligth-medium body. Overall: Very good and impressive. Way better than what I expected. Not too cloying acid-wise. I would gladly drink some more of this. 9/4/9/3/17 [Rating for B2: Pours blond/golden with low white head. Some lacing. Aroma is of fruits, apricots, very slight bile. Taste is of fruits, sugar, acidity, sourness, citric? Palate: Light body. Nice balance. Overall: Pretty good. Not too acid, wich is appreciated. Very nice gueuziness. Sweeter than b1? Maybe just because it is younger... Very good anyways. Sticking with higher score. (3/9/9/4/16)

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2014 10-28-2012. Bottle (750 ml). Batch 1. Shared by David Paquet, huge thanks! Straw color with minimal head and little to no lacing. Aroma of wood, honey, pineapple, leather and hints of apple. Taste is acetic with strong wood notes, pineapple, grapefruit. Tart finish. Mouthfeel is dry and astringent(!). Very nice beer! Like said by of my tasting partners (didnt remember who, Julien?), it was at his place in a lambic tasting, but also share some particularities with Saison style beers. 9-3-9-4-18 = 4.3

22-02-2014. Bottle (750 ml). Batch 2. Bottle from pandableh, thanks Dan for this one! Clear straw golden with a small white head and some lacing. Aroma is of lethery brettanomyces with gueuze-like funk, peaches/apricots, light acetic presence and buttery notes. Taste is slightly sweet and moderately sour with leathery brettanomyces, peaches/apricots, wood, funk and light vanilla. Medium body. Good carbonation. Dry finish. Very good American "Gueuze". A tad less complex (but still quite complex) than batch 1. I think one more year will do wonder with this one. One of the best exemple of the style in USA. 4-8-9-4-16 = 4.1

Bottle (75 cl), courtesy of _angst_. Clear golden, no head. Cidery grapefruit aroma with green apples, some vinegar, some barnyard. Light to medium bodied, medium to high carbonation. Dry with high acidity. A tad too much acetic acid for me.

(Bottle) Pours hazy orange with a small head. The aroma holds fresh broken wood, tart berries, tart apple cider, citrus, lacto, dirty barnyard brett, yellow fruits, star fruit, passion fruit, touch of phenols, hay, crackers and cheese. Tiny oxidation. The flavor is dry, heavily acidic and tiny bitter with notes of aggressive citrus, crackers, tart fruits, lacto, dirty brett, tiny phenolic, hints of wood and spices. The mouthfeel is tart and dusty with light carbonation. Touch of juniper. Lingering citric finish. Light to medium bodied.

750 ml bottle received in trade. Thank you Pandableh! Pours hazy deep reddish golden with a small frothy white head that quickly dissipates without leaving much trace on the glass. Smell is slightly sour and fruity with crackers, plums, dark grapes, dry soil, hay, buttery wood, dried flowers, leather, horse blanket, lemon juice, lychee, gooseberries, unripe currants, green apples, wood, star fruit, white wine and hints of alcohol. Taste is sour and tart with crackers, dry soil, hay, apple cider vinegar, green apples, lemon juice, lactic acid, dark grapes, unripe plums, lychee, passion fruit, peppery wood, leather, gooseberries, star fruit, horse blanket, lemon zest and unripe currants. Mouthfeel is mouth puckering, tart, dry and medium bodied. Finish is sour and tart with crackers, lemon juice, lemon zest, hay, dry soil, unripe plums, green apples, passion fruit and leather. Slightly too acidic but still quite good.

Bottle at USA comes to Skövde. Slightly hazy pale golden beer with a small white head. Sourish grapefruit aroma, rubber, leather, tart, citrus, hay, funk, wood, apples, vinegar notes. Sour rubber flavor, grapefruit, leather, citrus, woody, tart, lemon, elder, floral, dandelions. Quite nice with a really sour base.

Sampled at USSkovde
Hazy golden. Brief white head. 
Very sour aroma and flavour. 
Leather, barnyard, citrus. 
A bit too sour, vinegar.
Sampled at UCTS testing. Pours hazy yellow with a small white head. Smells sour, elders, white pepper. Tastes abit bananas, sour, canned fruit and bitter.

Bottle @ rlgks tasting. Pours cloudy pale amber with a small shortlived off white head. Aroma is sour acidy sweet yet has some salty hints honey fruity lemon zest. Flavor is sour acetone lemon fruity apple vinegar tart nicely bitter astringent. Finishes sour tart and aseingent bitter.

Review #200

Thanks to Bulldogp04 for sharing this guy in line at the CBS release. Served in a Deschutes snifter.

A: Pours a hazy golden yellow with spritzy white head that dissipates to some swirls.

S: There is actually some considerable funk in there, nice tart lemon skins and some sour apples. A nice woody oak character as well. 

T: The taste follows the nose. Its nice to see some funkiness in there, nice oaky flavors with a sharp tartness. Some sour lemon as well. Really great.

M: Light bodied with a nice dry finish. Little pucker in there.

O: Delicious. Im surprised at how funky this has become. I didnt really expect that. Great flavor profiles. I dont know if Ill ever get the chance to try this again, but I can cross my fingers and hope.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-30-2011
pours pale gold with no head. Aroma of sour grapes and green apples, slight vinegar.  Taste follows, nice funk with the fruit, pretty sour.  very smooth and drinkable.  Really good!
Bottle at RBSG 2012. Pretty peach-orange color. Big, funky, acidic citrus nose. A lot of citrus. Extremely sour flavor, very acidic, fruity citrus. A great beer.

I shared a bottle of this with drabmuh and our wives last Sunday.

The label art is fantastic and hilarious. The beer appears mostly clear, with just a slight haze. The color is golden yellow, with a small head and just a touch of lacing.

The aroma is sour and funky, but not overly so. Straw and hay scents with a slight barn or farmyard presence. Very enticing.

The beer is so easy to drink. I am very impressed. It tastes incredibly smooth and clean, and all of the complexities are balanced very well. Masterfully done. As we delved deeper into the bottle, the beer gets slightly more sour and funky. Hooray dregs. The finish is tart and funky with a hint of vinegar, but no burning acidity.

An awesome beer and well worth tracking down.

750ml bottle. Somewhat hazy amber with a white head. First impression was strange as it smelt exactly like the syrup left in a can of peaches...after a few minutes though it opened up, became quite tart, bit of lychee, light barnyard, and some apple notes. Full body, moderate carbonation, lots of funkand fruit, becomes slightly more sweet yet tart and dry. Very happy to try this one.

Sampled this at a sour tasting that Tomme Arthur showed up at out of the blue at. Poured like a hazy orange color, with virtually no head whatsoever. Aroma was very mellow, but when I actually took notes the beer may have been a bit cool out of the fridge. Dont remember what it was like once it warmed a bit so, darn it. Flavor was a bit tart, with some light ester notes. Perhaps some earthy notes to it?

served in a Lost Abbey stemmed glass. pours a slightly tinted orange and dull yellow. not much head on this but a nice fizzy head that stops and hangs on for a bit. tons of green apple and white grape. light hints of concord grape. nice light oak through out. faint hints of vinegar . nice and sour. appears most of the sourness comes in the form of sour green apple and a slightly lighter white grape. a nice sweetness with a touch of concord grape beneath. funk in the back. mostly fruit here.
slightly sweet and moderately carbonated. nice dryness in the end. 
this is great, very well blended and very refreshing. not overly sour but quite sour in general. Reviewed on: 11-20-2010

Huge thanks to gkost for sharing this one.  Cheers, Gary!  Pours a hazy as hell yellow-orange with a white head.  Nose is vinegar, citrus, lemon, tart fruit, and oak.  Flavor is similar with oak, vinegar, lemon, citrus, and lactic flavors.  Medium in body and lingering vinegary tartness in the finish.  Amazing and an awesome beer.

750ml bottle corked and caged shared by gkost at Markwises bday bash, thanks Gary.  Poured a light yellow color, aromas of light tart apricot, lemon zest, and light barnyard.  Flavors are the same, refreshing as hell in the heat, great beer overall.

Rusty with the share!  Porus a hazy golden color with a white head.  Aroma is funky with some ripe pit fruits.  Taste is sweet with plenty of sourness.  Medium bodied and dry. This is a really nice beer.  Many thanks Rusty!!

Auction win.

A incredibly balanced Sour. A nice hint of caramel malt, vanilla, lemon, oak, some spice with a sour finish. Excellent for the style.

Thanks to my friends storminnorman and daknole for sharing some wonderful beers..this pours cloudy yellow...an overall  tarty experience with some lemony flavor..a lot going on here perhaps some grapefruit and a touch of vinegar.  This is a magnificent sour...really enjoyed it.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2017 My Bottom Line:
Citrus fruit, celery salt and white wine vinegar are awash in acidity, while chewy wheat succeeds in providing diversity.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A veil of foam covers the cloudy blond.
-The nose on this one is as intense as a Hanssens Oude Gueuze, to give you an idea. Maybe not as complex, but thats quite the aromatic wallop nonetheless!
-The soft, natural carbonation helps the mouthfeel greatly.
-Drinkability is quite low because of the acetic intensity.
-The finish lasts as long as their Framboises (which is very intense).

Bottles.

Pours a thin headed golden straw. Smell is nose burning vinegar and acetone notes. Taste is very dry sourness, apple cider vinegar, oak and vanilla. Kind of sharp on the finish too, with more lemon and citrus as the beer warms.*Third or fourth time Ive had DDG with the first being pretty mellow and kind of a mild sour smarties taste to it whereas the last couple have been harshly sour to me.

From notes.  First reviewed 10/31/2011.  Poured from a 750 mL bottle into a tulip. Thanks to bauermj for bringing this out to the whale tasting.

My pour is a very hazy light golden straw color with a light off-white head that fades away to nothing. 

The aroma is so sour it burns my nose a little bit. Pure sour, lemon zest, some grapefruit, and a bit of apricot.

The light malt is there but gets quickly overwhelmed by the lemon, lactic, and vinegar sourness. Very sour throughout, which I enjoy very much; that is really the focus of the beer. Lemon, a bit of white grape and green apple with some full grapefruit sourness to finish.

Smooth but bitingly sour and tart mouthfeel. Medium bodied, crisp carbonation.

I really enjoy sours that really burn my nose and rip my taste buds out. This satisfies that criteria.

Big thanks to Deuane for bringing this one to our gueuze tasting. Another long time want knocked off the list.

A - Pours honey yellow with a nice one finger tall white head leaving spotty streaks of lace down the glass. Goes a little dead in the glass after the first few minutes.

S - Smells of bright lemon zest, green apples, a bit of candied sweetness and some light vinegar toward the end. It gets a little funkier as it sits in the glass.

T - Starts off with a nice lemon twang up front quickly giving way to hints of granny smith apples, some candied sugar and a bit of earthy funk. The balance of tartness and sweetness is spot on. Finish is pretty tart, leaving the pallet dried for quite awhile after the finish.

M - Medium body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Crisp, tart feel that leaves the pallet dry long after consumption. It has a really good balance of flavors throughout.

O - I really enjoyed this one. It had a ton of flavor but it was much easier to drink than some of the other wilds I have had. I would have loved to have tried this one fresh when it came out.

750 ml bottle sampled on several occasions. This one a pours a hazy golden orange color and topped by a small, foamy pure white head that quickly recedes leaving a sudsy wash that rejoins the body below. The aroma shows a very lambic like profile with ample amount of fruit, citric acidity, and dry funky barrel notes. Notes of sour apricot, nectarine oranges, and peaches show prominently along with tart grape skins and some barnyard funk. The aroma is just fantastic. The flavor follows suit and does not disappoint in the least with huge notes of soured apricots and peaches along with grapefruit like acidity that is assuaged by the soft oak and the musty, funky yeast. The citrus acidity is mouth puckering at points, but never overbearing as the oak, vanilla, and funky yeast keep things dry and in check. Medium to full bodied with subtle yet persistent carbonation that enhances the citrus acidity and also bone dry thanks to the funky yeast profile. The palate is just perfect with the rich amount of heft and the classic lambic like dryness. This is just delicious stuff and I am anxious to see how it does with some more age on it. This is a truly masterful creation and a world class effort from Tomme and the Lost Abbey. Awesome stuff and one of the best beers Ive ever tried.

DDG pours a hazy golden color.  It honestly looks like apple juice.  No head is poured and no lacing.  There are bubbles that shoot from the bottom of the glass to the top.  Of course as you get deeper and deeper into the bottle that clearness goes away and becomes cloudy.

Smell is all the way tart apples.  Its the number one thing I noticed.  Tartness and sourness mixed together wonderfully.  I also picked up some lemon, grass, citrus, and oak. 

The taste is more sour than I remember.  It could be because of some of the age.  This time around while my girlfriend liked it she didnt quite love it.  I ended up finishing almost the whole bottle by myself.  I never have issues really finishing a whole bottle but when there is a sour ale involved it eventually gets pretty damn puckering.  The sour and tart apples once again take front stage followed by barnyard funk, lemon, citrus, and a oaky finish.  If I could describe this beer to someone I would say its Acidic, tart, funky, sour apple juice mixed in with wine like qualities. 

Mouthfeel is dry, mouth puckering, medium bodied, and acidic.  Good carbonation.
Ausgewogen säuerlicher Beginn, der im Mittelteil etwas stärker aber deutlich trockener wird. (Gering) süß-säuerlich, kurz brennend, wenig bitter, ausgewogen, süffig. 11/11/13/11/14/11
Second time I had this and this is very different. Starts to come around as it warm up. Nice and funky and the soursness really starts to come our

Pours a transparent golden color, bubbles floating to the top, thin limited white head.  The nose has a fair bit of sourness and acidity, light leathery brett, an earthy funk, touch of tangerine and tangy peach.  The earthy funk is there with some barrel presence, hints of vanilla, the peach is sour, extremely high acidity and burns the throat.  The feel is full bodied and heavy, grainy on the throat, dry, under carbonated.

2009 bottled. This is absolutely amazing, Tart, incredible. I am so happy. The  appearance is opaque and cloudy, I am in love with this beer. The sour is such a perfect balance to me. There is not enough to describe. Actually if this entire post was just to say "you have to try it" at would be enough.
Yellow/gold pour with some haze and creamy head and lace. Bretty Belgian yeast and some bread. Super sour and bready. Medium/light bodied very very nice beer.

A top want provided by Chris @ MikeDashGs 30th Birthday Party at stone. So glad I got to finally try this beer. Pour is a funky Belgian lemonade with some creamy white foams forming a pretty hat on a pretty beer.  Smells like an old lemon jam. Lots of cobwebs and dusty old oakiness that gets me excited. Taste is musky old lemon, tart with a slight citrus vinegar. Not a lot of cheesiness in this one, as its very clean. Some vanilla helps make the taste memorable, but really this is a very clean and crisp tasting wild ale. The lemon is musky as can be, an old lemon with all the vibrancy of a fresh one off the vine. The feel is effervescent with a slow but consistent release of bubbles. This is amazingly drinkable, but I wouldnt have minded even more tartness. This beer might be going through a subdued phase.  Dont miss this one, its a really great beer.

Tasted on 8/2/11 from a 750mL corked and caged bottle obtained in a trade.  Pours clear brassy orange with an average white head that slowly recedes to a spotty layer of lace.  The nose is awesome; very sour with lemon acidity, a bit of barnyard funk, the lightest hint of caramel malt, very light baking spices, and a beautiful light oaky vanilla aroma backing everything up.  The flavor is very sour with a ton of lemon acidity, barnyard funk, light baking spices, and the same vanilla backbone.  The body is medium with light carbonation, and a long, tannic, lemon acidic and slightly vanillin finish.

Bottle from hbmason...thanks Tim! - Pours golden amber with a thin off-white head. Light citrus smell, with nice understated, light vinegar tartness. A little bit of cheese and light peach. Taste is nice and tart, with the same cheesy funk, but its pretty smooth. Nice vinegary tartness on the finish, with a little Sweet-Tarts. Nice and light in the mouth. Very nice.

750 ml bottle shared by STLWill- thanks, Will! Pours a pretty basic looking clear gold with a small white ring of a head. Aroma of lactic acid, oak, lemon, white grapes, funk, herbs, and a little yogurt. Amazing flavor of lemon citrus, white wine, vinegar, lactic acid, vanilla, oak, and herbs. Just a wee bit of funk but a high level of tartness and acidity. Light-medium bodied, with a sour, dry mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Top-notch sour.

Unclear yellow beer with a fine white rim. Pretty sour nose, like unripe grapes, and Bretts galore. Clean sourish flaovur, with a nice retronasal smokey, sulphuric flavour, which makes it resemble and old, lightly saccharinated gueuze. Remarkable balance. Refreshing, wheatslickness, better bodied than expected. Slight acidburn. Very nice try. Nose promises punch of acids, but it turns out milder on tasting.  Many thanks to Evan & Matt!

One of my white whales, and it did not disappoint. This was sampled side by side with some of the other top yet readily available guezes and it slayed them all IMO. It pours golden with a white head. The aroma is powerful with funky musty basement, lots of vanilla, oak, pears and apricot. The sour fruitiness was challenged only by the wonderful barrel notes throughout. The funk was a nice support. The flavor is very fruity and tart with lemon, orange, tangerine, vanilla and oak with solid brett funk in a very tart finish. An explosive geuze with lots of fruit and sour even after 4 years in the bottle. A masterpiece.

bottle from RBWG-cloudy yellow hue witha fizzy white head.  sour and funky nose with a bit of grainy sweetness.  very pleasant!  sour flavors-yeasty and pretty funky.  cant really pinpoint whats going on here hwoever, its a very well done american sour ale.  the finish is short, kind of ends abruptyly but still very good.  There are not many american brewers out there that can brew this style this well.

Bottle from South Bay Drugs: Poured an extra thick haze of sediment near opaque in a glowing yellow hue. Tiny formation of film layer head that seemed to dissipate in a matter of seconds. In the nose, there is a very fruity aroma and has similarities to freshly cut kiwi, mango, and cranberries along with a funky Belgian yeast. The flavor is sour and delicious being how subtle it is between the new and old barrel aged blends being combined together. Does allow little room for the fruit to come out again in the flavor but the yeasts and there Belgian funkiness dominate.

Shared this with some FLA buds. Poured a nicely carbed, hazy gold color with a thick creamy head.  Straw and citrus nose with grapefruit, lemon zest and a touch of woodiness. Great sour taste with hints of apple and barnyard funk. Finished dry and lightly acidic. Another nice beer from Dr T.

25.4 oz bottle.  Clear orange yellow with traces of white froth.  Nose is lemon pith, apricot, marshmallow and earthy funk.  Medium light with a faint sparkle.  Taste is lemon peel, vanilla yoghurt, tomatillo, green melon and sour apple.  Good gueuze but not great.

enjoyed during 2011 RBWG bottle pours hazy yellow with a medium white head.  Aroma is semi-sweet and I swear I smell lemonheads.  Flavor is mellow in the fact that its not too acidic or vingary in nature, but easily one of the tartest beers at the tasting.  Tart lemon juice, peel, bitter wood elements.  Nice stuff.

The beer is honey gold with a touch of orange. The head is white rising a finger and lasting only briefing with ligh lacing.

The aroma is pretty light for a wild ale with mostly a light sour funk to it. Its on its way to being a crazy strong horse blanket but jusnt get you there. Some might like the lighter aroma as it wont turn them off, but I was looking for a tad bit more pugency. At the end there is some light wood. 

For the reasons I didnt like the aroma a ton, I love the taste. It is sour enough to give me the pucker and sensations that I love about wild ale but its just light enough to make it very drinkable. The biggest complaint is that the flavor isnt complex just sour through and through.

Mouthfeel is heavy and great drinkability.

Overall this is an excellent ale and great beer overall. If you love sours this is one you have to search out.

Big thanks to the awesome guys from the super secret beer den for sharing this one with me at lost abbey. Smells awesomely sour with citrus and Brett notes. Taste is sour fruits, Brett, Lemon zest, and oak. Very well balanced clean beer. Very drinkable and glad I was finally able to try some.

Bottle at RBWG. Pours clear golden, thin white head, quickly reduced to naught. Nose is super-dry, scorching acid, lemon, salt, horse, so dry, yet still clean and pretty. Flavours of salt, aggressive lemon, big funk & cheese. Parchingly dry. Cool stuff.

Sampled at Hunaphus release. Thank the Lord above for this beer. It was the end of the day and my palate was pretty much shot but Im very happy I got to try this before I left. The taste and aroma was absolutely lovely. Tart and sour with hints of citrus. Cheeks puckered and my got larger. An absolute treat.

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2011 Bottle cracked open at Hunahpus.  A hazy shade of orange with a small white head.  Sour fruits and woody nose.  All kinds of things going on in here funk, lemon zest, tart citrus, and horse blanket flavors.  Its fantastic, I just cant decide if I like it better than CC or not.

Bottle shared by someone at RBWG 2011, thanks 
Appearance: Hazy orange with a small white head and some light spotty lacing 
Aroma: Sour fruits, sweet oak 
Taste: Sour fruit, sweet malts and oak 
Nice and drinkable.

750 ml bottle shared at RBWG, thanks! Pours a cloudy orange color with a medium white head. A sweet woody nose, some vanilla and light fruit akin to apricots. The flavor is surprisingly mellow, but that doesnt mean bad, actually it is damn good; lots of wood, vanilla, sour earthy flavors like a unblended lambic, very tasty. Lovely beer, complex and so drinkable.
A funky brett nose, with some green apple. Fruity sour cherry lemon. Sour, but balanced with soft fruit flavors.  Very good.  Wish i could get more.

Corked bottle. Golden color. Oak, vanilla, apple, honey and lemon in the aroma. Sour, oaky flavor with vinegar, honey, lemon and vanilla. Great complexity, but also a few raw edges. A great beer, comparable to the better geuzes.

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2013  Poured into a tall snifter. Straight haze golden appearance, with outrageous, snowflake lacing. Aroma of funk, tart cherry, farmhouse, wheat, lemon zest, grapefruit, hops, and granny smith apples. Medium bodied, yet intensely sour, tight, sticky, juicy, complex palate. Finishes with an aggressive bite on the back of the tongue and a lingering sour tartness upon the tongue. This is one of the most masterfully crafted, well-executed, wildly delicious beers I have ever tasted in my life.
sample at sour tasting.  Number two for the night, right behind cable car.  flavor of lemon, tart, and the usual LA funk.  very different from cable car but very close in overall greatness.

Opened at my new years beer blow out, thanks Amy for bringing this one. Pours clear yellow with small short lasting head. effervescent bubbles keep this lively. Aroma is tart and funky with lots of lemon, grapefruit, a touch of honey like sweetness. . finish is dry and light with lasting citrus and funk. fantastic beer

Huge thanks to daknole.  Bottle pours hazy gold with a white head.  Aroma is lactic and funky, showing notes of lemon, grapefruit, wood, and barnyard. Flavor shows the same with some additional sour peach, green apple, and a touch of white vinegar.  Overall body is moderate, dry and moderate to heavy acidic. Damn good stuff.

Bottled sample via and shared with oakbluff. Gold in colour with strong carbonation. Loads of funk on the nose, backed by herbs, wood, raw wheat, and very faint sour apple. Citrus elements, especially lemon, are very strong in the mouth, blending with more funk and faint herbs. Very long finishing and intense.

I had a small sample of this at a BA fest last year ago and Ive wanted to try it again ever since. Big thanks to my cousin Greg for sharing a bottle on Christmas. Pours Orange gold, topped with a medium sized off white head. Aroma of lactic acid, oak, white grape juice and citrus, especially orange. Flavor is much tarter than the aroma. Orange and lemon hit the palate initially, but are soon overcome by lactic acid. Peach and apricot build towards the finish. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. One of my favorites from Lost Abbey.
Bottle. Pours apricot. Nose and taste of tart fruit, lemon and orange rinds, funk and oak barrel. Nice full body for the style.
Cloudy golden with a small white head. Aroma of funk, fruit and wood with a touch of acetone, unfortunately. Dry and tart flavour with berry and wood and a hint of vinegar

Purchased at the Pizza Port Carlsbad back in early August. Sampled on September 15, 2009.

A: Beautiful golden, tawny apricot color with a fairly long-lasting bone-white head. The initial head on a semi-hard pour into my tulip glass was a little over an inch, and it has settled down to a little over a quarter of an inch. Rich effervescent bubbles immediately after the pour settle into a mild vertical flight of carbonation as the brew settles. The lacing clings mildly as I quaff the beer down.

S: A prickly sourness is the most apparent scent upon first sniff. As I bring the glass back for another whiff, I smell sweet Meyer lemons alongside sour green grapes and a few tropical notes. Theres also a slight oakiness, which I gather will assert itself further as the beer warms from fridge temperature. As it warms, there is a little more of a slightly funky earthy aroma. 

T: As with the nose, there is a mouth-puckering tartness as I take my first sip; it takes my mouth a moment to adjust, and my eyes have gotten a little watery. While Im certainly no sour expert, I wouldnt recommend this as a beginners wild ale. As I get further into the glass I can detect a lot more--the lemon is much less pronounced in the taste, and coming further is more of a Granny Smith-type sourness.

M: The tartness is obvious and the first sip made my lips pucker and left my cheeks quite dry; the dryness subsides as my palate becomes more accustomed to the beverage, but the refreshing acidic tartness remains throughout. The carbonation is fairly light, which is very nice and refreshing on what is hopefully one of the last hot days here in Northern Virginia. My biggest complaint is that this is something my taste buds were able to adjust to a little too much, as the last sip wasnt nearly as puckering as the first couple. Also, while not a style that needs plenty of carbonation, this one could use a tad bit more.

D: Drinkability is quite high; as I took my second sip, I was saddened by the fact that I had only another 700 mL or so of this tart, puckering nectar. While this may not have been the kindest year to Lost Abbey, Duck Duck Gooze is certainly making the brightest impression upon me.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-15-2009
750ml bottle pours a hazy yellow with a thin, creamy white head.  Nose of spices, white pepper, bretty, horsey.  Flavor is tart, lemons, vinegar, peaches.  Full bodied, tart finish.

75cl bottle, thanks ?  Minimal white head atop clear light amber body.  Aroma is medium sweet, vinegar, lemon, some funk.  Taste is medium sweet, lemon, funk, some vinegar.  Light-medium body, rather acidic.

Aroma:Sour aroma, fruit, some sweetness.

Appearance:Murky yellow orange. Low head, fair lacing.

Taste:Huge sour bite right on the foretaste. Tons of lemon flavor. The aftertaste has some white grape skin sour flavors. Also, some sweet notes linger on pleasantly.

Palate:Light to medium body, with medium to heavy astringency on the throat.

Overall:Amazingly drinkable sour beer. Not as sour as some beers, its really drinkable.

Bottle thanks to wetherel: Pours a clear deep golden brass with a thin ring of wispy-lacing white head.  Aroma of fresh lemon zest and tart oak with some mild hay funk.  Starts with good complexity and light sweetness with a crisp tart acidity and oaky balance before a puckering tart finish.  An enjoyable and authentic gueuze that should age well.

Big thanks to Dan or sharing this one! Poured a hazy gold with a white head that dissipated completely. Aroma was full of very sour fruits (nearing acetone) with a bit of lemon with some funk. Flavor has a great sour fruit note with some lemon and oak coming through with just a hint of backing funk.

On tap, Monks Cafe.  Pours a slightly cloudy yellow gold body with minimal to no head.  The nose is funky, sour, and sweet with a good bit of brett, acetic acid, and a slight nod toward some of the real Gueuze like musty cellar and barnyard notes.  The flavor is a little too overly acetic for my tastes, it starts to burn the throat after a while.  Rather sour and puckering, a lot of the subtleties that might be lurking in there are covered up by the sourness.  You realy have to try hard to pick out the barnyard and bretty notes.  Spritzy fizzy carbonation.  Not bad, but doesnt live up to the billing for me.
Bottle at Papsøs - Thanks. Cloudy amber/golden - white head. Barnyar, horsey, fruity, peppery, sourish, bretty, cactus, oakey, ok wooden, medium carbonation. Very nice drinkability.

Bottle shared by plovmand in the Pavilion. 
Pours a hazy orange colour with a white head. 
Aroma is dry grape, wood, a hint of apples, dust and dirt. 
The flavour is lovely acidic with notes of wood, dry grape, apples and a dusty vinegar hint.
Thanks a bunch for sharing! :-)

Bottle at Papsø.
Hazy golden coloured with a small white head.
Light acidic aroma of oak and acetone.
Light acidic flavour of oak and acetone.
Tart finish.

Bottle. Pours an opaque amber orange color with a nice white head. Strong sour notes and tart fruit in the nose. Some acetone notes as well but very minimal. LIght mouthfeel with a really nice blend of flavors. Fairly sour but not so much that it leaves you puckering. Lemon and straw notes. The acetone notes in the aroma are there in the taste as well but again, very minimal. Finishes dry and clean. Good lace left behind of the glass. A very solid beer that lives up to the hype. Some wine like characteristics. Not sure how this beer really gets any better.

Hazy golden with a medium sized off white head. Sour nose with horseblanket, brett, barnyard, wood and hay. Sour flavor with brett, horseblanket, wood, hay, lacto and sour apples. Finished dry and sour. Lovely!

Entered to celebrate my rating number 18,400. Bottled. A hazy golden beer with a lazing white head. The aroma has notes of brettanomyces, wood, and lemon. The flavor is sour with strong notes of grapefruit, brettanomyces, lacto, and wood, leading to a very tart finish.

Bottle. Hazy yellow, off-white head. Aroma is right away citrusy and sour, brett, some subtle wood notes. Citrus notes, sweet and sour dominate the flavor profile, leading to a dry finish, leaving you wanting more. Well done !

Thanks a bunch for opening this Mike.
Cell phone notes.

Clear golden, off white head, minimal lacing. Acetic, brett, lemon, apple, and oak. Up front acetic bite with a sharp lemon peel, very bright taste. Light body, medium carbonation, slightly tannic, and dry finish. I never had it fresh, but from other reviews it seems the acetic character is starting to take over. IP still wins in complexity.

Bottle from choprite.  Pours a rusty golden color that looks almost orange once in the glass with a fluffy eggshell head that settles to a thin layer.  Huge whiffs of sour lemons in the aroma that go along with barnyard funk, acidic notes, and straw.  This packs a pretty intense sour punch while being remarkably drinkable.  This is a good summer sour as I found it rather thirst quenching.  Wouldnt be hard to finish an entire bottle.  Sour lemon flavor once again leads the way.  Theres plenty of acidity along with tannins, oak, and sour apples.  Some peach as well to give it a slight tropical fruit nod but then I quickly get back to the sour lemon.  An excellent beer.  Would love to try it again.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2010 Hazed golden pour with a white head.  Bright citrus sour aroma with subtle funk.  Well carbonated body with a smooth, moderate mouthfeel.  Tastes lemony and very tart, moving to pleasant barnyardy funk, earth, and hay.  Im finding it hard to put into words just what makes this so good.  Maybe its the way it tingled and clung to my mouth for so long after each sip, and how very easy it is to drink considering how puckering sour it is.  Quite a joy.

Thanks, Mark. Had this at Liquid Sunshine XI. Haze bright yellow appearance. This looks so delicious. Aroma is of lemons, citrus fruit, and a slight funkiness. Not much wood coming from this one, in terms of aroma, but a very pungent aroma. Mouth-puckering sour flavor is insanely good. This has a lovely lemon tartness that I have never experienced before. Again, Im not getting much from the wood, but holy shit, that lemon sour/funk flavor is mind blowing. Nice and fizzy texture, brings this effervescent beauty alive. Id have to say, it is more heavily balanced on the lemon sour side. Great brew.
Wheat beer appearance, decent head, hazy. Sweet tart nose with a good dose of wheatiness. Sweet tart sour body, somewhat "barny". Swirling sour tart, wheat fields, and barnyard on the finish.

750. Corked and baled. Thanks mark. Pours a cloudy medium gold with a loose and short lived white film. Huge lemony grapefruity funky delicious nose. Immediate promise of greatness to follow. Creamy fizzy medium body. Lemons, wet grass, slight barnyard, amazingly complex and delicious.
Little tart wheat, some yellow mustard, hibiscus. foggy tarnished gold, clear on the edges. divinity in a glass. gently magically tart, sick. visceral reaction, just great.

Funky, lactic, acidic nose. Lots of lemon, good deal of poop. Nice sour tart aroma. Pours hazy yellow, not much head or lace. Super funky and lemony flavors. Big funky finish. Well carbonated, light body, very citric. Super fucking sour, tons of lemon. Nice.

Bottle shared at RBSG 2010. Poured a hazy yellow color with an average frothy off-white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate to heavy sour, yeast and wood aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy sour flavor with a medium to heavy sweet & sour finish of moderate to long duration. This is a standout beer for style.
On draft at Stone Sour Fest 2010. Off-yellow pour. Aromas of lemon and yeast, taste as more of the same, lovely sourness.

Glowing clear golden color/ off white head. Nice dry lemon, dry hay, mild barnyard aromas. light to medium bodied.  Jaw bracing tartness at first yields flavors of again dry hay, sour lemon, rustic barnyard- very tasty drink, and very much gooze like.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: /50 ml bottle. Beer from trade. Thx Kevin. This is without doubt my favorite LA-lable work. Corny big time. The pour is screming orange with a really nice white head. Spot on. The nose is pretty sharp with hint of green grapes and soaked bread. The taste has a nice blend of sourness with some sweetness and a hint of lacticness. The presens of young grapes are constantly with a lot of fruityness. The mouthfeel is medium and gives a briliant mouthfeel. It has the trademark of LA and is classic in that way - but damn its nice in a simpel way. Really drinkable  - I want more. Who has these bottles. Ship em over

Beautiful golden yellow pour with a thick and full white colored head, that fades into thick lacing, carbonation is about perfect for the style. Aroma was lemon zest, shaved vanilla, and hints of grapefruit and grass. Upon first sip there is a very sharp and tart lemon  profile, followed by a slight sweetness and finally horseblanket funk on the finish. Very acidic, anymore so and this beer would be too harsh. This one definatley walks the fine line of something wonderful and an epic mess of a beer...still though Lost Abbey pulls this one off pretty well. Not nearly as well rounded as true Gueuze but done fairly well.

Appearance:  Pours a dull cloudy amber gold with a white ring of head. 

Aroma: Lemon, funk.

Taste: Lemon, attic, distilled vinegar. Very tart and sour. The malt was very faint and took a backseat to all of this sourness and funk.

Mouthfeel: Medium bodied, low carb, slightly chunky.

Overall: Very complex, a super bold and puckering sour.

On tap pour at Sour Fest.  Beautiful hazy, straw/gold in the glass.  Fluffy head with large bubbles.  Mellow funk aroma.  Dry tart taste with sugary overlay (a sugar injected gueuze).  Lingering gummy sour tart in the finish - quite amazing.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2013 5th March 2010Pre ZBF. Bottle courtesy of Alex 4:20 - Cheers Mate! Second time Ive had this but no better than the first! It just goes too far for me. Pale hazy gold beer. Light dry palate. Lemon - sharp and sour and acidic. Really dont understand this type of Sour - my loss unfortunately! 2.415th October 2013Tasting at Bruces new pad. Thanks to Colin for the opportunity of trying this overrated beer again! Hazy gold beer with a small white head. Light palate, slightly crisp and with fine minerally carbonation. Medium sourness, a little wood. Sherbet lemon that is slightly acid. Finishes semi dry with an acidic aftertaste. My palate has come round a lot more to this style in the last 3 years but I still dont see what is special about this one.

750 ml corked and caged bottle poured a clear golden yellw with a small lingering white head. Aromas of apple vinegar, lemon, barnyard and light straw. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a dry tart finish. Flavors of straw, lemon and light biscuit with a crisp dry tart lingering lemon finish.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: Rich, bright hazy yellow body. Centimeter tall white cap which receded to a nice white foamy skim. Spotty lacing.

S: Pungent, sour lemon blasts from the bottle upon opening. Wet hay, farmhouse like funk.

T: Nice lactic sourness. Lemon-orange juice. More funk. Slightly earthy and grainy. Tasty.

M: Good carbonation rush on the tongue. Slightly puckering. Clean, sour finish.

O: Easy drinking considering the amount of sourness and funk here. Definitely a winner from Lost Abbey. Glad I hunted this down

Draft at Monks during Philly Beer Week 2010.

Beautiful golden with fluffy cream colored head and persistent lacing.  Bubbles emanating from the bottom of the glass throughout the drink.

Aroma was butter and lemon, along with some vanilla and hints of grapefruit and grass.

Great tart lemon up front and some nice vanilla earthy funk on the finish.

Slight acidity and great carbonation, relatively light body.

Overall, another fantastic and drinkable sour from Tomme..
Botella. Thanks Plovmand.Cloudy deep golden orange.  Sour tart fruity citrus aroma. Niiice. So good fruity tart citrus hoppy great flavour.  Great sour!

Bottle. Thank for that treat, Dakine. Hazy golden with a creamy white head. Tart acidic aroma with notes of leather, barnyard, fruit, citrus and orange peel. The flavour is tart and sour with lovely acidic notes. Citrus, lots of fruit, oranges and some citric hops in the finish. Great beer!

cloudy orange, smooth white head.
nice sour and acid aroma. a little stingy. overall very nice aroma.
flavor is very sour, very acid, but still balanced and quenching. citrussy base kicks ass. nice.

2009 bottle shared by badnewsbeers. Murky, hazy apricot body with yeast sediment, thin ring of off-white carbonation. Funky, tart, sour nose, with pineapple and lemon, hints of bubblegum, spice, and tannic oak. Tart body with firm sourness but also musty penicillins or cheese rind, opening up into sugary, fermented berries and wet hay. Good complexity and nice balance among sour funk, sweetness, and oak. A very good beer.

750mL Bottle. Many thanks, Andy, Im very grateful for your generosity. Well-yeasted and musty nose, with obvious acidity and a decent range of Belgian bug products. Pours a evenly hazed orange-gold, with a clean white rim. Flavors are strong and complex, if a little uneven. The acidity is incredibly strong, pointed, and sharp, out balance, really. This is not the soft, elegant acidity of a mature Belgian example, but the brash mineral-laden, multi-bug acidity of an overly-aggressive American brewer. Oak weaves in and out and a milk-like yeastiness pops up from time to time. The lambic-like signature character is there, but it ebbs towards acetate and scotch tape at times. Long oaky dryness in the backend. All I can think is that it doesnt measure up to most Belgian lambics. It could use some elegance and refinement.

On tap at Capones. Tangerine body, thin white head. Nose of peach and pale malt, heavy funk, and a bludgeon of acidity, overwhelmingly so. The flavor is balanced between tart fruits and pale malt, but again, finding these among the vinegar is damn tough. The Lost Abbey yeast definitely shows up somewhere in there, reminiscent of Yellow Bus. This burns the back of the throat and coats the lips. Not for the faint of heart. Actually very similar to YB except that the acid here is off the charts and the peach relatively absent.
Golden orange pour with white head. Aroma of oak, peach, sour funk, Berry and light alcohol. Big gueze like body, huge in sour oak, lemon, clove and vinegar. Vinous in nature.

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2015 Draft at monks during Philly beer week. Pours a bright full hazy orange body with thin white lacing. Aroma is insane - extreme tart and sour fruit. Palate is perfect. Notes of tart, citrus, orange, sour fruit, sweet fruit, slight funk. Young v/s old bottles with Vinny, Frank, Ryan, Paul and others. much thinner and effervescent overall. Light vinegar creeping in with some minor acetone showing its ugly face as well. The old batches seem to be past its prime at this point (2015).

Draft at Monks for Tomme Arthur night with James and Dallas. Poured into a tall snifter. Straight haze golden appearance, with outrageous, snowflake lacing. Aroma of funk, tart cherry, farmhouse, wheat, lemon zest, grapefruit, hops, and granny smith apples. Medium bodied, yet intensely sour, tight, sticky, juicy, complex palate. Finishes with an aggressive bite on the back of the tonge and a linger soury tartness upon the tongue. This is one of the most masterfully crafted, well-executed, wildly delicious beers I have ever tasted in my life. Definitely worthy of a perfect 5.0. Surreal.
Really good beer that andrew hasnt tried. Super awesome. Did I mention andrew hasnt tried this?

RBSG09.  An excellent sour. Light yellow and murky liquid with good lacing. The smell is mostly sweet and sour lemons with a refined funk. The flavor is pleasantly sour, and the beer is quite drinkable. The malt gives the beer a refined sweetness. Its a refreshing gueuze with an easily likable flavor. While I like strong funk and sour flavors, this is still an excellent gueuze.

750mL bottle of batch 1, shared with ryan and erice as part of a blind tasting on 5/21/2010.  Pours a slightly hazy, whitish yellow, with half a finger of head.    Aroma is sour with citrus peel and an interesting herbal note underneath.  Taste is extremely acidic with lots of lemon peel, as well as some sweet citrus fruit.  Finish is quite sour.  Needs to tone down the acidity a bit.
caged and corked 750 ml.  pours a straw yellow with little head.  great aromas of citrus and funk.  Great sourness, a top notch geuze

I rated this a couple months ago but some how it never got recorded.  Heres take two.  Part of a blind lambic tasting hosted by ryan.  This one was very sweet, almost overpowering compared to the others.  It let up as we drank a bit more.  Poured a clear straw yellow with a thin white head.  Sweet tinge to the aroma with the usual funky sour aroma you expect from a lambic/sour.  Fruity with a hint of melon.  Sweet.  Lots of sourness, but sweetness dominates when it first hits the tongue.  Sourness takes over with a strong creamy oak finish.  Some funk.

Pours hazy golden with white head, aroma is some grass and floral hops leading into deep horse blanket, cheese, and barnyard.  Taste up front is a bit of subdued hops, leading into the vinegar, acetic, blasting sour with notes of horse and cheese.  A bit thin on the mouthfeel, and a dry finish.  Definitely glad to try this one, one of the best sours out there!
frisk, gylden, blød og meget drikkelig geuze. Uklar, fløde agtig kort skum.

Bottle 750ml.[ Trade by toncatcher ].  [ As my rating # 14000 on ratebeer ]. Clear medium yellow - orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy tart, sour, wood, barnyard, bretty, grapefuit - citrus tart. Flavor is heavy sweet and acidic with a long duration, dry dry, fresh. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. On the night a great sour .. ;O) and big smiles a round the table. [20100416]

Straw colored, with some haze perhaps due to the massive carbonation. Aroma is full of grass and barnyard, with pleasant hints of lemon. The flavor has tons of funk and citrus with a powerful lactic sourness. Perhaps a little one note, but delicious and clean.

Pours a hazy yellow color with minimal fizzy head.  Nose heavy on vinous acidic funkiness.  Quite sour with light lemony fruit notes, some yeast presence, faded notes of oak.  Quite nice, looking forward to the other settling bottle.

Aroma is cheesy, funky barnyard, hay, citrus, and lemon rind.
Taste is gauzy cheese, funky hay and barn, citrus, mild bitterness, and loads of sourness and cheese rind.
Finish is sour as fucking hell, bitter cheese, and citrus rind.
Lingers forever.
Wow. Aggressive, and awesome.

On tap.  Poured a lightly hazy, bright yellow-orange color with a thin white head that faded to a ring.  Sharp, lightly acetic aroma with hints of horse blanket, barnyard yeast, straw, and citrus (lemon).  Crisp, sour entry that quickly transitions into an aggressive, biting acidity with hints of funky barnyard yeast and tart citrus fruit that lingers into the finish where it is paired with a light cobwebby dryness.  Crisp, tight carbonation paired with the acidity creates an inviting, biting mouth feel.  Overall, a nice, aggressive beer that was easy drinking.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2016 Fresh funk aroma.  Chalky hazed golden color with a sudsy white head.  Fresh lemony tart flavor with a light carbonation.  Flavors were lively and lingered well.  My favorite wild beer at the event.

Notes: Bottle at the Denver Rare Beer Tasting 8, during GABF Week 2016.

Previous Rating (added 5/2/2010, updated 3/24/2012) - 7/3/6/3/15 = 3.4:
Farnhouse tart, apple-cider-ish nose.  Hazy gold-brown, cider-like color.  Tart and citrusy green apple and pretty clean finish.
